data.name: Check if IP is in given Network
data.description:
Write a function which returns `true` if an IP Address is in a given IP Network. Besides the IP address the function receives the subnet mask and the start address. All addresses are given as strings. As Example, if you have a very basic network like: subnetmask = `255.255.255.0` start adress = `192.168.1.0` The function should return `true` for adresses in the network like: `192.168.1.2` and `false` for adresses not in this network like: `192.168.2.5`. So but how the hell can we do that ? Well first of all you have to understand how IP addressing works, if you are completely new to that look it up [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPv4#Addressing) or just googling for IP-addressing. If you have a base understanding and just need some hint on how to begin, then let me help you a bit: As you surely know the subnet mask gives you the number of hosts in a given network. In our example above would that be 255 rigth ? Then as we know, if we represent the mask `255.255.255.0` in bits, the first 0 will mark the start point for our range which gives us exactly 255 possible numbers. `11111111.11111111.11111111.00000000`
--------------------------------------^ Well basically 253, since the first and last addresses are reserved in a network but that hasn't to bother us in our task. What is interesting for us is, that we'll have always `1` in our subnet mask as long as our network ID is... Moment what the heck was the network ID again.. Let me demonstrate that with a picture:

Now as we now know the behavior of the network ID and that the subnetmask will always have `1` in this spot, couldn't we use that behavior with some bitwise operations ? Maybe compare mask, ip- and start-address in some way? Have Fun! :)
